awd_titl_txt: Conference: Conference on Enumerative and Algebraic Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Conference on Enumerative and Algebraic Combinatorics will take place at the University of Florida in Gainesville, Florida, February 25-27, 2024. The conference will feature 25 invited and contributed talks by leading researchers in the field as well as a poster session. By bringing together those working in both the Enumerative and Algebraic Combinatorics communities, attending researchers will have ample opportunity to learn about recent developments and develop new mathematics.

The aims of the conference are to present outstanding recent developments in both enumerative and algebraic combinatorics, with a particular focus on their overlap. Specific topics will include standard Young tableaux, permutations, partially ordered sets, symmetric functions, lattice paths, and compositions, all of which are amenable to both enumerative and algebraic study.  For more information see the conference web page: https://combinatorics.math.ufl.edu/conferences/sagan2024/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded travel for early-career researchers and other participants to attend the Conference on Enumerative and Algebraic Combinatorics, held February 25-27, 2024, at the University of Florida in Gainesville. NSF support enabled the attendance of 26 researchers, many of whom would not have been able to participate otherwise.

Enumerative combinatorics focuses on precise and approximate counting, while algebraic combinatorics applies algebraic methods to solve combinatorial problems and vice versa. Key tools in algebraic combinatorics—such as symmetric function theory, representation theory, and the incidence algebra of partially ordered sets—have deep connections to classical enumeration. These structures, in turn, are governed by combinatorial principles that invite further enumerative study. The interplay between these areas is central to modern combinatorics.

The conference featured 24 research talks, including a plenary address, and a poster session with 21 presentations. Topics included chromatic and symmetric functions, Schur positivity, matroid theory, Coxeter groups, permutation patterns and statistics, polytopes, partially ordered sets, and combinatorial aspects of representation theory. Timed to coincide with Professor Bruce Sagan's 70th birthday and retirement, the event brought together 64 mathematicians, fostering collaborations between junior and senior researchers and providing newcomers with a broad perspective on the field through both formal presentations and informal mathematical discussions.


 


Last Modified: 02/25/2025
Modified by: Vincent   Vatter
